III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section Sufficiency of staff.
Description (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
1

rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A continues to run away from the facility. It is unknown why
the youth continues to AWOL but there are concerns that the staff
are not protecting the youth.
Investigation Interviews:
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/29/2025.
Staff 1 reported Youth A had attempted to AWOL multiple times
since being placed at the facility. Staff 1 reported the facility was
taking precautions regarding Youth A by having him on a one on
one observation due to the truancy attempts. Staff 1 reported
when Youth A or any other youth attempts to leave the facility staff
follow them to the street corners on either side and if they go past
that and do not return for 15 minutes the police are called. Staff 1
could not recall if Youth A would AWOL with other youth or by
himself each time.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/29/2025.
Staff 2 reported Youth A would escalate and attempt to AWOL
each day he was at the facility. Staff 2 reported Youth A was
triggered easily by other youth or by something like not having the
flip flops he wanted. Staff 2 reported due to Youth A’s risk of
AWOLing and self-harming behaviors he was kept on a one to
one and a staff was with him at all times. Staff 2 reported in
addition to the one on one a supervisor was kept close by as well.
Staff 2 reported he and other staff would attempt to talk to Youth A
to help calm him down but that did not always work. Staff 2
reported when Youth A would leave the premises staff would
follow until the street sign turning left out of the facility or the
bushes to the right. Staff 2 reported at this point police are
contacted. Staff 2 could not recall if Youth A had attempted
AWOLing with other youth around.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/29/2025. Supervisor reported Youth A was on a one to one due
to his risk of AWOLing. Supervisor reported Youth A would
escalate in some manner on daily basis. Supervisor reported staff
would attempt to redirect Youth A verbally back on site and would
follow Youth A to the bush on the right. Supervisor reported staff
do not follow past this point as the cameras do not have a view
past this point and to avoid staff being accused of anything.
Supervisor reported Youth A would AWOL by himself but one of
2

the times he went with Youth B and Youth C. Supervisor could not
recall if other youth were in the area during the AWOL attempts.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/29/2025.
Staff 3 reported Youth A liked altercations and would taunt staff
like he was going to leave. Staff 3 reported when Youth A or any
other youth leave the facility staff follow until the fire hydrant and
the stop sign because the cameras do not show past those points.
Staff 3 reported the moment youth go AWOL police are contacted.
Staff 3 reported no concerns with the steps followed regarding
Youth A’s AWOL attempts.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/29/2025.
Youth B reported he went AWOL with Youth A and Youth C one
time recently. Youth B reported staff followed the youth up to a
certain point then stop because they cannot go too far away from
campus. Youth B reported police get called. Youth B reported
Youth A would AWOL each day he was at the facility and he was
on a one to one. Youth B reported staff tried asking them to stop
and come back to the facility. Youth B could not remember which
staff were there during their AWOL attempt.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/29/2025.
Youth C reported he went AWOL with Youth A and Youth B.
Youth C reported staff try to ask them to come back and say that
they are trying to keep them safe. Youth C reported when they do
not listen staff follow them to the street sign. Youth C was not
aware if police are called. Youth C did not recall what staff were
there at the time.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the hospital on
8/21/2025. Youth A reported everything was fine while at the
facility. Youth A reported he would AWOL because he wanted to
and not for any real reason. Youth A reported staff would watch
them and call the police if they left. Youth A reported having no
concerns with staff or supervision at the facility. Youth A denied
being hurt at the facility.
Documentation Review:
• Incident Report (IR) SE-32674 dated 7/29/2025 states
Youth A asked to go outside when he attempted to leave
the campus. IR states line of sight was lost and police were
called.
• Incident Report SE-32651 dated 7/25/2025 states Youth A
asked to go outside for some air and walked away from
campus. IR states line of sight was lost.
3

• Incident Report SE-32729 dated 7/30/2025 states Youth A
returned from AWOL.
• Truancy Policy Statement states a client who leaves
Wolverine Human Services property without supervision
and authorization is considered to be truant. A youth is
determined to be AWOL/Truant when they are out of line of
sight for 15 minutes.
Video Footage Review:
• There is no video footage available
Analysis There are no rule violations established regarding this allegation.
Per interviews staff made efforts to provide supervision to Youth
A. Per interview, Youth A did not have concerns with staff or
supervision at the facility.
Technical Assistance:
The facility shall clarify in WHS Residential Services Truancy
Policy and Procedure the definition of line of sight and complete a
updated training with staff to ensure understanding and
consistency. The clarification should include all specifics on
physical locations which staff no longer follow youth off the
campus.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
